item.title: No PS Needed! How to Use Gemini 3 to Generate Professional US Stock Financial Calendars in One Click (Tutorial Included)
item.content:encoded:
No PS Needed! How to Use Gemini 3 to Generate Professional US Stock Financial Calendars in One Click (Tutorial Included)

Section titled ‚ÄúNo PS Needed! How to Use Gemini 3 to Generate Professional US Stock Financial Calendars in One Click (Tutorial Included)‚Äù

For those following the US stock market, every month is packed with macro data, earnings calendars, and major events. Typically, we have to gather information from various websites and then painstakingly layout a ‚Äúone-sheet summary‚Äù.

Previously, creating such charts required mastery of Photoshop or Canva. But now, with Gemini 3, you only need one reference image and a pile of messy text to generate a professional-grade financial calendar in minutes.

Today, I‚Äôll walk you through how I used Gemini 3 to create a ‚ÄúDecember US Stock Financial Events Calendar‚Äù. The process was incredibly smooth, and the local editing capability in the final step truly amazed me! üëá

Step 1: Prepare Materials to ‚ÄúFeed‚Äù the AI

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 1: Prepare Materials to ‚ÄúFeed‚Äù the AI‚Äù

You can‚Äôt make bricks without straw. We need to prepare two things:

  1. Reference Style Image: Find an old calendar image with a layout you like. (I found a financial calendar; I liked its color scheme and timeline layout).

  1. Text Information: Compile important US stock events for December and January (such as Non-Farm Payrolls, Powell‚Äôs speeches, Broadcom earnings, Christmas rally, etc.) into text to send to the AI.

üí° The key here is: You don‚Äôt need to format the text; it can even be messy news excerpts. The AI will extract the key points itself.

Step 2: Let Gemini ‚ÄúCopycat‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 2: Let Gemini ‚ÄúCopycat‚Äù‚Äù

Open Gemini 3, upload the reference image from earlier, and enter the Prompt:

Prompt: ‚ÄúReferencing the calendar style in the screenshot, generate a calendar of important time points for US stocks in December and January based on the following content.‚Äù (Attach the compiled text content‚Ä¶)

Gemini responded very quickly. It rapidly identified the visual structure (Layout) of the reference image‚Äîdates on the left, icons in the middle, text on the right, and the color style at the bottom.

Generated Result (First Version): AI perfectly replicated the timeline style, and the icons were matched accurately (e.g., chip icons for chip earnings, a Christmas tree for Christmas).

‚ö†Ô∏è However, a small flaw appeared: The AI was too ‚Äúfaithful‚Äù to the original image and actually drew the Logo ID (watermark) from the reference image in the top left corner. This is obviously not what we wanted.

Step 3: God-tier Operation ‚Äî Natural Language ‚ÄúRetouching‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 3: God-tier Operation ‚Äî Natural Language ‚ÄúRetouching‚Äù‚Äù

Previously, in this situation, we would have to download the image, open PS, use the spot healing brush to remove it, and then add our own Logo.

But now, you just need to say one sentence to Gemini.

I hope to replace the Logo in the top left with my own brand ‚ÄúVibe Sparking‚Äù.

My Modification Instruction: ‚ÄúTop left corner, below ‚ÄòOne Sheet Summary‚Äô, left of ‚ÄòRate Cut Expectations Rising‚Äô, inside the box, please change to Vibe Sparking. Keep other areas unchanged.‚Äù

This tests two of the AI‚Äôs capabilities:

  1. Spatial Localization: Understanding directional terms like ‚Äúbelow top left corner, left of‚Äù.
  2. Inpainting/Local Editing: Changing only the specified area without destroying pixels in other parts of the image.

Step 4: The Moment of Miracle

Section titled ‚ÄúStep 4: The Moment of Miracle‚Äù

Gemini 3 quickly provided the second version feedback.

‚ú® Final Result: Look at the image below. The area that originally copied the Logo has been perfectly replaced with ‚ÄúVibe Sparking‚Äù. The font style and background color blocks blend perfectly with the overall image, with no sense of violation. Meanwhile, the rest of the calendar (dates, icons, text) remained 100% consistent without any distortion.

üìù Summary and Thoughts

Section titled ‚Äúüìù Summary and Thoughts‚Äù

Through this test, Gemini 3 demonstrated three powerful core capabilities:

  1. Style Transfer: Accurately understanding the color scheme, layout, and design logic of the reference image.
  2. Info Viz (Information Visualization): Transforming unstructured long text into clear, structured charts.
  3. Multimodal Editing: This surprised me the most. It‚Äôs not just ‚Äúgenerating‚Äù, but ‚Äúediting‚Äù. Change where you point, greatly lowering the barrier for ordinary people to create professional charts.

In the future, for event posters, schedules, or even long meeting minutes, as long as you have a good-looking ‚Äúsample image‚Äù, you are a professional designer!

item.title: AI US Stock Market November Key Events Investment Research Report
item.content:encoded:
I. Overview of Core Events and Market Impact

Section titled ‚ÄúI. Overview of Core Events and Market Impact‚Äù

In November 2025, the US stock market faces a complex situation interwoven with five major categories of critical events, which will profoundly impact market direction. Based on current data analysis, the market is in a delicate balance of high valuations, low volatility, and high uncertainty.

  • The Supreme Court‚Äôs Tariff Ruling (November 5) is the biggest uncertainty factor this month. The Federal Court of Appeals has ruled that tariffs (reciprocal tariffs and fentanyl tariffs) implemented by Trump based on the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) were illegal. The Supreme Court will hold oral arguments on November 5, with a final ruling expected in late 2025 or early 2026. This ruling involves a risk of nearly $200 billion in tariff refunds. If the Supreme Court overturns the tariffs, the market may see significant positive news; if it supports the government, it implies continued trade uncertainty.
  • Sino-US trade relations saw a brief d√©tente at the end of October. After meeting in Korea, a one-year truce agreement was reached: the US will reduce tariffs on Chinese goods from 57% to 47% (fentanyl-related tariffs from 20% to 10%), and China will suspend rare earth export restrictions for one year. However, this is merely a tactical truce, not a structural solution. Both sides retain the option to restart the trade war, and the risk of escalation in November should be watched.
  • The government shutdown has lasted 29 days (as of October 31), making it one of the longest in US history. The Congressional Budget Office estimates the shutdown will result in $7-14 billion in permanent GDP loss. The suspension of key economic data releases creates a ‚Äúdata black hole,‚Äù forcing the Federal Reserve to formulate policy without core data on employment, inflation, etc. Approximately 750,000 federal employees have been furloughed, and SNAP (food stamp) benefits will cease on November 1, further impacting consumer demand.

II. In-depth Analysis of AI Investment Sector

Section titled ‚ÄúII. In-depth Analysis of AI Investment Sector‚Äù

1. Palantir (PLTR) ‚Äî Valuation Bubble Risk

Section titled ‚Äú1. Palantir (PLTR) ‚Äî Valuation Bubble Risk‚Äù
  • Earnings Release: Q3 on November 3. Stock price year-to-date +170% to $194.55, market cap $442.5 billion, P/E 648.5. Expected Q3 revenue $1.1 billion (+50%), EPS $0.17.
  • Risk Assessment:
    • Extreme Valuation: Highest P/E in S&P 500. Q2 revenue first exceeded $1 billion, but market cap rationality requires years of high growth to materialize.
    • Dependence on Government Contracts: Although it has a multi-billion dollar long-term contract with the US Army, policy adjustments may compress orders.
    • Intensified Competition: Salesforce launched a national security business directly competing.
    • Analyst Caution: Divisions exist alongside valuation anxiety.
  • Opportunities:
    • Strong Commercial Segment (+93% YoY), robust AIP demand; deepening cooperation with Oracle and Snowflake; a billion-dollar contract with the British Armed Forces signals international expansion.

2. AMD ‚Äî Interplay of Expectations and Reality

Section titled ‚Äú2. AMD ‚Äî Interplay of Expectations and Reality‚Äù
  • Earnings Release: Q3 on November 4. Stock price year-to-date +115% to $254.84, P/E 152.6. Company guidance Q3 revenue $8.7 billion (¬±$0.3 billion, +28%).
  • Growth Drivers:
    • AI Chips: Instinct MI400 and Helios systems offer cost-effectiveness advantages, clear data center positioning.
    • Server upgrade cycle and AI investment drive demand.
    • Management confident in sustained growth.
  • Risk Factors:
    • High base for performance, ‚Äúmeet target thenÂõûË∞É (pullback)‚Äù risk; technically overbought.
    • Export restrictions impact.
    • Valuation and slightly reduced consensus expectations bring compression risk.

3. NVIDIA (NVDA) ‚Äî Market Bellwether

Section titled ‚Äú3. NVIDIA (NVDA) ‚Äî Market Bellwether‚Äù
  • Earnings Release: Q3 (FY26) on November 19. Stock price year-to-date +134% to $202.89, P/E 57.64, market cap nearly $5 trillion.
  • Key Highlights:
    • Strong Blackwell demand, GB200/GB300 targeting LLM, inference, and robotics, representing a generational leap.
    • ‚ÄúLong-term inference AI‚Äù narrative strengthens the logic of computing power demand.
    • FY25 revenue $130.5 billion (+114%), Non-GAAP EPS $2.99 (+130%).
  • Risks:
    • Trade and export restriction uncertainties.
    • Intensified competition and domestic substitution.
    • Concerns about AI valuation bubbles.

4. CoreWeave ‚Äî High-Growth Newcomer

Section titled ‚Äú4. CoreWeave ‚Äî High-Growth Newcomer‚Äù
  • Earnings Release: Q3 on November 10. Listed in March 2025, Q2 revenue $1.213 billion; expected Q3 revenue $1.28 billion.
  • Growth Story:
    • Positioned as ‚Äúthe essential cloud for AI,‚Äù with high-quality clients.
    • Revenue surged year-over-year, reflecting explosive demand for computing power.
  • Risks:
    • Insufficient profitability: Q2 EPS -$0.6, Q3 expected -$0.512.
    • Capital intensive, high cash flow pressure; intense competition with cloud giants.

5. Tesla Shareholder Vote ‚Äî Governance Uncertainty

Section titled ‚Äú5. Tesla Shareholder Vote ‚Äî Governance Uncertainty‚Äù
  • Date: November 6. Vote to approve Elon Musk‚Äôs $1 trillion compensation package (voting power concentration 27%).
  • Core Issues:
    • Compensation based on stringent performance milestones.
    • Musk hinted at leaving if influence is insufficient, company needs contingency plan.
    • Institutional opinions divided, results may be close.
  • Market Impact:
    • Stock price year-to-date +105% to $440.10, P/E 231.63. If rejected, it could trigger governance instability and stock price pressure.

III. Federal Reserve Policy and Market Liquidity

Section titled ‚ÄúIII. Federal Reserve Policy and Market Liquidity‚Äù

1. October Rate Cut Completed, December Path Uncertain

Section titled ‚Äú1. October Rate Cut Completed, December Path Uncertain‚Äù
  • Rate cut of 25bp on October 29 to 3.75%-4.00%, internal dissent.
  • December rate cut probability decreased from 90%+ to approx. 68%-75% range.
  • Powell emphasized December is not a foregone conclusion; inflation remains elevated, employment under pressure, and data gaps exacerbate uncertainty.

2. End of Quantitative Tightening and Liquidity Inflection Point

Section titled ‚Äú2. End of Quantitative Tightening and Liquidity Inflection Point‚Äù
  • Quantitative tightening of Treasury securities ends on December 1, continues monthly MBS reduction of $35 billion.
  • Rising funding costs, increased use of repurchase agreements; reserve balances near ‚Äúample‚Äù levels.
  • Ending QT aims to avoid a repeat of liquidity events, but it‚Äôs not a signal of easing.

3. Policy Risks from Data Black Hole

Section titled ‚Äú3. Policy Risks from Data Black Hole‚Äù
  • Government shutdown led to suspension of key data releases (employment, retail, CPI).
  • Decision-making ‚Äúflying blind,‚Äù December may be forced to pause rate cuts; businesses and investors become more conservative.

IV. Systemic Risk Assessment

Section titled ‚ÄúIV. Systemic Risk Assessment‚Äù

1. AI Investment Bubble Risk

Section titled ‚Äú1. AI Investment Bubble Risk‚Äù
  • Several financial leaders warned of overvaluation and sudden pullback risks.
  • Data supporting concerns:
    • Huge capital expenditures mismatched with commercial returns.
    • High concentration of index returns and profit contributions from top companies.
  • Counter-arguments:
    • Investment seen as a necessary cost to maintain leadership;
    • View that overall valuation still matches fundamentals exists;
    • Ample funding runway, explicit returns may take longer.

2. Industry Impact of Tariff Uncertainty

Section titled ‚Äú2. Industry Impact of Tariff Uncertainty‚Äù
  • Affected industries and companies:
    • Apparel Retail: VF, Gap, Williams-Sonoma experienced pullbacks.
    • Semiconductors: Microchip, Western Digital under pressure.
    • Medical Devices: GE Healthcare declined.
    • Automotive and Parts: Polaris affected by Mexico factory tariffs.
    • Consumer Electronics: Best Buy pulled back due to supply chain exposure.
  • Research shows tariffs and uncertainty can cause long-term S&P pullbacks of 7%-10%, explaining nearly 10% of volatility.

3. Valuation Pressure and Market Sentiment

Section titled ‚Äú3. Valuation Pressure and Market Sentiment‚Äù
  • Valuation: S&P forward P/E 22.7, higher than 5-year and 10-year averages; trailing P/E 28.8 is high.
  • Volatility: VIX 16.92 below average, reflecting complacency.
  • Earnings: Q3 2025 S&P +9.2%, Tech +22.3%; 2025/2026 expected +11%/+13.9%. Growth highly concentrated in leading tech, may converge in the future.

V. Investment Strategy Recommendations

Section titled ‚ÄúV. Investment Strategy Recommendations‚Äù

Short-term Strategy (November)

Section titled ‚ÄúShort-term Strategy (November)‚Äù
  • Primarily defensive, reduce highly valued single holdings to below 5%-8%.
  • Focus on event-driven opportunities:
    • 11/3 PLTR: If revenue growth <50% or Q4 guidance is conservative, expect 15%-20% pullback; if exceeding expectations and AIP new clients are strong, hold.
    • 11/4 AMD: Watch data center revenue and MI400 orders; if not meeting $8.7 billion guidance, may pull back to around $230 technical level.
    • 11/5 Supreme Court Argument: Do not bet on direction, focus on skepticism towards executive power; tariff-sensitive stocks may rebound.
    • 11/19 NVDA: If Blackwell orders and gross margin exceed expectations, may lead a new round of increases; if 2026 guidance is lowered, AI sector will be pressured.
  • Hedge Volatility:
    • Consider small VIX call options to hedge tail risk.
    • Allocate 10%-15% to defensive sectors (utilities, consumer staples), such as Costco and other counter-cyclical targets.

Mid-term Strategy (Q4 2025 - Q1 2026)

Section titled ‚ÄúMid-term Strategy (Q4 2025 - Q1 2026)‚Äù
  • Thematic Diversification:
    • AI Infrastructure prioritized over pure applications:
      • Semiconductor Equipment: ASML, Applied Materials, etc.
      • Power/Energy: Focus on utilities benefiting from surging data center electricity consumption.
      • Data Center REITs: Digital Realty, Equinix, etc.
    • Dual-wheel Defense Tech:
      • Palantir: If growth is sustainable, can be a 3%-5% long-term core position.
      • Traditional Defense: Lockheed Martin, Northrop Grumman, RTX, etc.
    • China Concept Stock Rebound Opportunities:
      • TSMC, NetEase, and other undervalued high-growth targets; position ‚â§10%, set stop-loss.
    • Rate Cut Beneficiaries:
      • Finance and REITs moderately benefit, focus on valuation and dividends.

Long-term Strategy (2026 and Beyond)

Section titled ‚ÄúLong-term Strategy (2026 and Beyond)‚Äù
  • Quality and Valuation Discipline:
    • Stick to core holdings: MSFT, Alphabet, AMZN, Meta, etc.
    • Avoid valuation traps: PLTR, TSLA require high growth to match valuations, beware of PEG > 3 situations.
  • Global Allocation to Hedge Geopolitical Risk:
    • European defense, Japanese semiconductors, Indian IT to diversify risk.
  • Risk Management:
    • Stop-loss: Decisively stop-loss if single stock pullback > 15%.
    • Position Sizing: Total tech position not exceeding 50%, single sector not exceeding 25%.
    • Cash: Retain 15%-20% for pullback opportunities.
    • Rebalancing: Quarterly review, consider partial profit-taking if YTD gain > 100%.

VI. Conclusion and Outlook

Section titled ‚ÄúVI. Conclusion and Outlook‚Äù
  • November is a critical watershed: Tariff rulings, AI leader earnings, and the Fed‚Äôs path will shape Q4 and 2026 landscape.
  • AI investment differentiation: Infrastructure and platforms with real revenue and customers offer more certainty.
  • Policy uncertainty becomes the norm: Need to adapt to increased volatility.
  • Valuation is elevated but not a full bubble: Risks concentrated in extremely overvalued individual stocks and some startups.
  • Recommendation: ‚Äú70% Defensive + 30% Offensive‚Äù: Quality leaders and hedging tools as foundation, supplemented by event-driven opportunities.

November Timeline

Section titled ‚ÄúNovember Timeline‚Äù
  • 11/3 (Monday): Palantir Earnings ‚Üí Government contracts and commercial growth verification
  • 11/4 (Tuesday): AMD Earnings ‚Üí AI chip competitive landscape
  • 11/5 (Wednesday): Supreme Court Tariff Argument ‚Üí Trade direction signals
  • 11/6 (Thursday): Tesla Shareholder Vote ‚Üí Corporate governance and personnel stability
  • 11/10 (Monday): CoreWeave Earnings ‚Üí AI cloud demand verification
  • 11/19 (Wednesday): NVIDIA Earnings + Fed Meeting Minutes ‚Üí Dual consideration of AI and monetary policy
  • 12/9-10: FOMC Meeting ‚Üí Clarification of rate cut path

Current market presents both opportunities and risks. Maintain discipline with data and logic, exercise moderate restraint in a ‚Äúlow volatility + high valuation‚Äù environment. Warren Buffett‚Äôs famous quote is worth noting: ‚ÄúBe fearful when others are greedy, and greedy when others are fearful.‚Äù

Note: This report is based on public information analysis and does not constitute investment advice. Investment involves risks, and caution should be exercised when entering the market.

item.title: Tech Giants‚Äô Q3 Earnings and Investment Playbook: AI‚ÄëDriven Opportunities and Risks
item.content:encoded:
In Q3 2025, U.S. tech giants delivered a mixed set of results. While the industry continues to benefit from the AI wave, performance diverged meaningfully. Google posted a historic milestone, surpassing $100B in quarterly revenue for the first time; Microsoft kept steady momentum with strong cloud and AI traction; Meta, meanwhile, was hit by a one‚Äëtime $16B deferred‚Äëtax charge under a new U.S. tax law, triggering a 9% share‚Äëprice drop. In this market setup, investors need to capture opportunities precisely while balancing risk.

Q3 Earnings Snapshot: Divergence in the AI Era

Section titled ‚ÄúQ3 Earnings Snapshot: Divergence in the AI Era‚Äù

Google: A Historic Breakthrough with Across‚Äëthe‚ÄëBoard Beats

Section titled ‚ÄúGoogle: A Historic Breakthrough with Across‚Äëthe‚ÄëBoard Beats‚Äù

Alphabet set a new record in Q3, crossing the $100B mark for the first time with $102.3B in revenue, up 16% y/y and well above the $99.85B consensus. EPS reached $2.87, up 35% y/y.

The standout was Google Cloud: revenue hit $15.16B, up 34% y/y and above the $14.72B street view. Backlog surged to $155B, reflecting strong enterprise demand for AI infrastructure. Search and Other posted $56.57B, up 14.5% y/y, underscoring that the core search franchise remains healthy even amid competition from AI assistants like ChatGPT.

Shares rose more than 6% after hours, as the market grew more confident in Google‚Äôs AI transition and cloud‚Äëbusiness acceleration. Management raised full‚Äëyear capex guidance to $91‚Äì93B, signaling continued investment in AI infrastructure.

Meta: Strong Operations, Accounting Shock

Section titled ‚ÄúMeta: Strong Operations, Accounting Shock‚Äù

Meta reported Q3 revenue of $51.524B, up 26% y/y and above expectations. But a ‚Äútax storm‚Äù flipped sentiment.

Under the newly enacted U.S. tax bill (‚ÄúOne Big Beautiful Bill‚Äù), companies must recognize accumulated deferred‚Äëtax assets in a one‚Äëtime reassessment. Because Meta holds substantial deferred‚Äëtax assets and has heavy U.S.‚Äëdomiciled equity, it recognized a one‚Äëoff deferred‚Äëtax expense of roughly $16B, driving an 83% y/y plunge in net income; EPS came in at $1.05, far below expectations.

Ex‚Äëtax effects, Meta‚Äôs ad and Reels businesses remained strong. AI‚Äëdriven ad targeting and performance continued improving, with sales growth at 23% ‚Äî outpacing Google‚Äôs 13% ‚Äî highlighting Meta‚Äôs lead in AI‚Äëpowered ad tech.

Management guided 2025 capex at $70‚Äì72B, with another major step‚Äëup in 2026. The aggressive investment plan shows Meta is spending heavily in the ‚Äúrace to AGI,‚Äù but it also raises near‚Äëterm margin and cash‚Äëflow concerns.

Shares fell 9%, reflecting market pessimism around the one‚Äëoff tax expense and elevated forward spending.

Microsoft: Steady Growth with AI Dividends Materializing

Section titled ‚ÄúMicrosoft: Steady Growth with AI Dividends Materializing‚Äù

Microsoft posted Q3 revenue of $77.67B, up 18.4% y/y and above the $75.49B consensus. EPS was $3.72 vs. $3.66 expected.

Intelligent Cloud revenue reached $30.31B, up 18%+ y/y, with strong AI workload demand continuing to power Azure. Business Software delivered $33.02B, up 15%+ y/y, with sustained growth in Microsoft 365 business subscriptions ‚Äî clear evidence of successful GenAI integration.

Free‚Äëcash‚Äëflow margin hit 33%, up sharply from 29.4% a year ago, indicating Microsoft is scaling while controlling costs and preserving cash‚Äëgeneration strength.

Valuation Benchmarks: Finding a Margin of Safety

Section titled ‚ÄúValuation Benchmarks: Finding a Margin of Safety‚Äù

Valuations vary widely. Google screens as most attractive with PEG 1.88 and P/S 8.95, paired with a solid 5‚Äëyear forward EPS CAGR estimate of 15.61%. Meta‚Äôs PEG is 2.17 ‚Äî slightly above Google‚Äôs ‚Äî but its faster sales growth (23%) and 5‚Äëyear EPS CAGR of 12.54% point to better growth optionality.

Microsoft‚Äôs setup is comparatively steady (P/E 39.70, PEG 2.35). While not as inexpensive as Google, its 16.86% forward growth outlook and 33% FCF margin reflect a superior business model.

Risk flags are clearer for NVDA and TSLA. NVDA trades at P/E 58.93 and P/S 88.59; despite a 5‚Äëyear growth rate of 91.83%, current multiples already discount very high growth ‚Äî arguably to excess. TSLA‚Äôs P/E of 308x is even more stretched while profits are falling this quarter ‚Äî the valuation is not supported by fundamentals here.

Why Meta‚Äôs Valuation Took a Hit While Google Outperformed

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Meta‚Äôs Valuation Took a Hit While Google Outperformed‚Äù

Meta‚Äôs $16B tax expense does not indicate fundamental deterioration; it stems from a one‚Äëtime accounting change. The new U.S. tax bill requires a comprehensive reassessment of accumulated deferred‚Äëtax assets. Meta was hit hard because of concentrated U.S. equity exposure, the abrupt implementation of the policy, and prior tax strategies being re‚Äëevaluated under the new rules.

By contrast, Google and Microsoft have more diversified deferred‚Äëtax asset structures, with a higher share of overseas equity, hence less impact from the change.

Investment Scenarios

Section titled ‚ÄúInvestment Scenarios‚Äù

Option 1: Balanced Growth + Safety Margin (‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ)

Section titled ‚ÄúOption 1: Balanced Growth + Safety Margin (‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ)‚Äù

Allocate Google 60% + Microsoft 40%. Google‚Äôs PEG is the lowest (1.88), Cloud growth is the fastest (34%), and market expectations remain conservative. Microsoft‚Äôs stability and cash‚Äëflow strength are exemplary. This blend offers growth with a margin of safety ‚Äî suitable for conservative, longer‚Äëterm investors seeking stable returns.

Option 2: Growth Seekers with Moderate Risk (‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ)

Section titled ‚ÄúOption 2: Growth Seekers with Moderate Risk (‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ)‚Äù

Allocate Meta 50% + Google 50%. Meta‚Äôs share‚Äëprice drop offers an entry opportunity; ex the one‚Äëtime tax, core operations remain strong. Meta‚Äôs AI‚Äëdriven ad engine and 23% sales growth outpace Google‚Äôs 13%, offering higher growth potential. If Meta‚Äôs AI investments start to pay off in 2026, shares could rebound 15‚Äì25%.

Option 3: Aggressive Growth with Higher Risk (‚òÖ‚òÖ)

Section titled ‚ÄúOption 3: Aggressive Growth with Higher Risk (‚òÖ‚òÖ)‚Äù

Allocate Meta 40% + Amazon 40% + Google 20%. Await Amazon‚Äôs Q3 print; rebalance if it beats. AWS and Advertising both appear to be re‚Äëaccelerating, with a 5‚Äëyear EPS CAGR estimate of 19.22%. This configuration leans on Amazon beating expectations; if results disappoint, adjust quickly.

Option 4: Absolute Avoid

Section titled ‚ÄúOption 4: Absolute Avoid‚Äù

Avoid NVDA, TSLA, and AAPL for now. NVDA‚Äôs 58.93x P/E and 88.59x P/S are at historical highs; any growth deceleration can trigger valuation compression. TSLA‚Äôs 308x P/E with sharply falling profit is a severe mismatch between valuation and fundamentals. AAPL‚Äôs P/E ~41 and PEG 4.27 imply the weakest valuation‚Äëto‚Äëgrowth pairing among the group.

Conclusion and Recommendations

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion and Recommendations‚Äù

Google, powered by Cloud acceleration and a comparatively restrained valuation, screens as the safest choice. Meta is building a long‚Äëterm moat via aggressive AI investment and ad‚Äëtech innovation; the current sell‚Äëoff creates opportunity. Microsoft remains the steady compounder ‚Äî a dual winner in cloud and AI.

Suggested portfolio weighting for most investors:

  • Google: 45%
  • Meta: 30%
  • Microsoft: 25%

This mix targets an 8‚Äì15% annualized return over the next 12 months while keeping volatility in a 15‚Äì20% band.

Note: This report is based on public information and is not investment advice. Markets involve risk; invest prudently.

item.title: From Exploration to Fix: How Claude Code Thinks and Reasons Through a SQLAlchemy Transaction Rollback Issue
item.content:encoded:
This technical blog is distilled from a real production incident investigation. It focuses on how Claude Code ‚Äúexplores ‚Üí thinks ‚Üí reasons‚Äù to quickly pinpoint the root cause, ship the smallest viable fix, and propose follow‚Äëup structural improvements.

The problem occurred in the mailflow service in production. The core error was:

From the surrounding logs, the failure happened when executing an INSERT into the emails table. Subsequent database operations then entered a ‚Äúcascade failure‚Äù state.

1. Context and Goals

Section titled ‚Äú1. Context and Goals‚Äù
  • Context: While handling inbound emails (parsing, creating records, forwarding, moving IMAP folders), mailflow occasionally fails the entire processing chain.
  • Goals:
    • Identify the primary trigger of the transaction failure;
    • Explain why all subsequent DB operations report the same error;
    • Restore processing with the smallest, lowest‚Äërisk change;
    • Provide structural improvement suggestions to increase robustness.

2. Exploration Path: From Symptoms to Evidence

Section titled ‚Äú2. Exploration Path: From Symptoms to Evidence‚Äù

Leveraging Claude Code‚Äôs code search and cross‚Äëcontext capabilities, we proceeded ‚Äúfrom symptoms to root cause‚Äù in order:

  • Locking onto logs and trigger point

    • The logs show the exception stems from the SQLAlchemy Session state: after a prior transaction failure, rollback() was not performed, leaving the current Session invalid.

  • Locating key code paths

    • mailflow/app/db.py: connection and session factory definitions.
    • mailflow/app/mail.py: main business flow, record creation, and commit points.
    • mailflow/app/utils.py: logging and WeCom notification entry notify_and_log.

  • Evidence 1: Module‚Äëlevel global Session

    • At the top of mail.py there is:
    • Once any flush/commit fails, this global Session becomes invalid, and all subsequent DB operations that rely on it will fail until an explicit session.rollback() is issued.

  • Evidence 2: Missing exception handling and rollback

    • Multiple session.commit() calls lack try/except/rollback protection:
      • Creating the mail record (create_mail)
      • Relating attachments to mail (_relation_attachment_and_mail)
      • Updating status when dealing with request results (deal_requests_result)
      • Large sections of the main flow in process_mail

Conclusion: The first failed DB operation puts the global Session into an invalid state. Because rollback() is missing, all later commits and even queries on that path fail with the same error, forming a ‚Äúcascade failure‚Äù.

3. Reasoning Chain: From Hypothesis to Verification

Section titled ‚Äú3. Reasoning Chain: From Hypothesis to Verification‚Äù

  1. Hypothesis: An INSERT/UPDATE exception (possibly from data constraints, transient network issues, or the pool) invalidates the global Session; without rollback(), subsequent steps (status updates, attachment relations, mail moves) all fail.

  2. Code verification:

    • Found the global session = session_factory();
    • Searched for session.commit() call sites ‚Äî most lack except: session.rollback();
    • This matches the error semantics exactly.

  3. Strategy: Move fast with minimal change to restore stability first, then evaluate structural refactoring.

4. Fix Strategy and Implementation

Section titled ‚Äú4. Fix Strategy and Implementation‚Äù

We prioritized the fix in three levels (P0 ‚Üí P2):

  • P0 (immediate, smallest change): add session.rollback() in exception handlers so the Session can self‚Äërecover.
  • P1 (comprehensive guard): wrap every commit() with try/except/rollback to avoid any single failure taking down the rest of the flow.
  • P2 (structural): replace the module‚Äëlevel global Session with scoped_session to isolate session state across processing flows (recommended, not mandatory for the hotfix).

4.1 Key Patch Snippets

Section titled ‚Äú4.1 Key Patch Snippets‚Äù
  • Add rollback in the main flow (mailflow/app/mail.py)
  • Guard status updates when handling request results (wrap both success and failure branches)
  • Guard establishing mail‚Äìattachment relations
  • Add protection for creating the mail record create_mail

4.2 Structural Optimization (P2)

Section titled ‚Äú4.2 Structural Optimization (P2)‚Äù

Eliminate the risk where a ‚Äúglobal Session drags down all flows‚Äù by using scoped_session:

Note: scoped_session provides better isolation in concurrent/multithreaded environments and reduces cross‚Äërequest contamination. The production hotfix first ensures rollback semantics are correct and complete; then evaluate the migration cost/benefit.

5. Validation and Regression

Section titled ‚Äú5. Validation and Regression‚Äù

Suggested validation steps:

  • Single reproducible mail replay: replay a previously failing mail and observe whether the chain recovers;
  • Observe logs: the message ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt reconnect until invalid transaction is rolled back‚Äù should no longer appear;
  • Manual spot‚Äëcheck: verify IMAP folder moves, forwarding, and database state;
  • Controlled load: increase the number of sample mails to ensure multiple commit points correctly roll back and continue.

6. Lessons Learned and Best Practices

Section titled ‚Äú6. Lessons Learned and Best Practices‚Äù
  • Anti‚Äëpattern: a module‚Äëlevel global Session, once invalid, causes chain‚Äëwide cascade failures.
  • Principle: every commit() should be wrapped by try/except + rollback; also rollback() in the top‚Äëlevel exception handler of the main flow.
  • Design: adopt a failure‚Äëresilient session model (scoped_session or acquire/release per processing unit).
  • Operations: log and alert immediately (this project uses WeCom via notify_and_log), and include key identifiers (uid, subject, time, to_list) in the message.

7. Claude Code‚Äôs Methodology

Section titled ‚Äú7. Claude Code‚Äôs Methodology‚Äù

This ‚Äúexplore ‚Üí reason ‚Üí fix‚Äù path generalizes to most code‚Äëlevel issues:

  1. Quickly bound the problem: start from the error semantics and match the most likely layer (transaction/session management).
  2. Evidence‚Äëdriven search: find the relevant files, variables, and functions (session_factory, commit() call sites).
  3. Hypothesize ‚Üí falsify/corroborate: propose ‚Äúglobal Session + no rollback ‚Üí cascade failure‚Äù, then find direct evidence in code.
  4. Smallest change first: add rollback() so the Session can recover and stop the bleeding.
  5. Structural improvement: propose scoped_session as the follow‚Äëup path, balancing benefit and migration cost.

Kimi CLI brings ‚Äúterminal + coding assistant + toolchain‚Äù into a single window. It feels like a shell, but you can switch to an agent at any time. It runs commands directly, plugs into Zsh, connects to Zed/VS Code (via ACP), and supports MCP tools. It‚Äôs in tech preview, but already usable for real work. See the official repo and docs for sources.

Why this is worth trying

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy this is worth trying‚Äù
  • Not a chat box, but a CLI that ‚Äúlands‚Äù work: one key to switch into Shell mode and run native commands; press again to return to the agent to explain logs, generate scripts, and complete parameters.
  • Works with Zsh: install the zsh plugin, hit Ctrl-K to toggle agent mode in the terminal‚Äîswitching back and forth is smooth.
  • Speaks ACP (Agent Client Protocol): this means it can be used as an ‚Äúexternal agent‚Äù inside editors like Zed. One protocol connects any editor with any agent‚Äîthat‚Äôs where things are heading.
  • Supports MCP tools: load third‚Äëparty tools via MCP conventions, like snapping in browser debugging and context search like Lego bricks.

By the way, Moonshot spun up the Kimi K2 / Kimi‚ÄëDev model line this year, focused on engineering and agent capabilities, emphasizing long context and coding ability‚Äîthe ‚Äúengine‚Äù behind this CLI track.

Install in two steps, take off in three

Section titled ‚ÄúInstall in two steps, take off in three‚Äù

Recommended to install with uv (clean and hassle‚Äëfree):

  • Install: uv tool install --python 3.13 kimi-cli
  • Upgrade: uv tool upgrade kimi-cli --no-cache
  • First run on macOS may pause ~10s due to security checks.
  • After install, run kimi --help to verify.

Initialization: run kimi in the directory you‚Äôll work in, enter /setup to bind; type /help to view the command menu.

Shell/Agent mode toggle: press Ctrl-K. Shell mode runs commands directly; built‚Äëin shell commands like cd aren‚Äôt supported yet.

Wire it up with Zsh

Section titled ‚ÄúWire it up with Zsh‚Äù

Install the plugin (Oh My Zsh example):

Restart Zsh and use Ctrl-K to enter agent mode; press again to exit.

Connect to your editor: the ACP way

Section titled ‚ÄúConnect to your editor: the ACP way‚Äù

Kimi CLI natively supports ACP (Agent Client Protocol), so editors like Zed can call it as an external agent. For example, add this to Zed‚Äôs settings.json:

Then create a new thread in Zed‚Äôs Agent panel to use it.

If ACP is new to you, think of it as ‚Äúan LSP for agents‚Äù: a unified way for editors to communicate with agents. The ecosystem is filling in quickly.

Six high‚Äëfrequency use cases

Section titled ‚ÄúSix high‚Äëfrequency use cases‚Äù
  1. Project cold start
  • Command: /setup to establish context ‚Üí have it read repo structure, generate a Makefile, and scaffolding scripts.
  • Value: more reliable than pure chat because it‚Äôs right in your working directory; scripts it generates can be run on the spot.
  1. Log firefighting
  • Run integration tests in Shell mode, pass failing stack traces to the agent for root‚Äëcause summaries and patches.
  • Flip back to Shell and validate the fix in one keypress.
  1. Command‚Äëline ‚Äúauto‚Äëcomplete++‚Äù
  • Ask it to compose grep/awk/jq pipelines based on your project context, and explain every parameter.
  • Great for large logs, CSV, and JSON batch jobs.
  1. ‚ÄúA terminal that can code‚Äù inside your editor
  • Use ACP with Zed: open an agent thread alongside code so it can both read files and run commands‚Äîtighten the edit‚Äëvalidate loop.
  1. Plug in third‚Äëparty tools (MCP)
  • For example, attach chrome-devtools-mcp for page performance analysis, or a context service for knowledge bases.
  • Start with: kimi --mcp-config-file /path/to/mcp.json.
  1. Faster onboarding for new teammates
  • Give newcomers a one‚Äëwindow ‚Äúask a command ‚Üí see explanation ‚Üí execute immediately‚Äù setup; no more ‚Äúask ChatGPT ‚Üí copy ‚Üí paste into terminal‚Äù ping‚Äëpong.

How it differs from a typical ‚Äúmodel chat box‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúHow it differs from a typical ‚Äúmodel chat box‚Äù‚Äù
  • Acts in place: after generating a command, it runs it directly‚Äîno copy/paste dance.
  • Editor‚Äënative collaboration: ACP lets IDEs/editors wire ‚Äúruntime context, file changes, task panels‚Äù together with the agent.
  • Pluggable: MCP brings external tools in; easier to reuse than a pile of proprietary plugins.

Who it‚Äôs for

Section titled ‚ÄúWho it‚Äôs for‚Äù
  • Anyone who wants to merge ‚Äúwrite script + execute + review‚Äù into one window.

Conclusion

If GUI Copilots are for ‚Äúwrite and peek,‚Äù then Kimi CLI is for ‚Äúwrite and run.‚Äù It pulls the agent out of the web page and into your terminal and editor, so each idea can quickly become an execution. It‚Äôs in tech preview now‚Äîperfect for early birds to get a head start and iterate.

item.title: Will Documentation-Driven AI Coding Become the New 'Spaghetti Mountain'? Pros and Cons of BMAD, Spec-Kit, and OpenSpec
item.content:encoded:
Remember the days when ‚Äúspaghetti codeüí©‚Äù used to give everyone a headache? With AI copilots like Claude Code, Codex, and Gemini in the mix, we have stumbled into a brand-new pitfall‚Äîthe ‚Äúdocumentation spaghettiüí©.‚Äù Documentation-driven AI programming has become a hot trend: write a clear specification first, then let AI generate the code. It sounds wonderful‚Äîno more guessing what the model wants, just provide a well-written brief and code appears automatically. The truth, though, is that if you take the wrong approach, the documentation can pile up into a brand-new spaghetti mountain that leaves you laughing and crying at the same time üòÖ.

Introduction: What on Earth Are BMAD, Spec-Kit, and OpenSpec?

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction: What on Earth Are BMAD, Spec-Kit, and OpenSpec?‚Äù

Let‚Äôs start with these documentation-driven AI programming tools that are making the rounds‚Äîthey each have their own personality:

BMAD Method ‚Äì a ‚Äúbig and comprehensive‚Äù framework whose full name is Breakthrough Method for Agile AI-Driven Development. Its ambitions are huge: it tries to simulate a complete agile squad with AI. There is an analyst AI, an architect AI, a developer AI, a tester AI‚Äîeach playing a role so that planning, coding, and testing all get staged like a full production. BMAD ships with a CLI and a web UI, plus special ‚Äúscript files‚Äù and context management so the AI team can collaborate. It usually unfolds in two phases: first the ‚Äúanalyst/product manager/architect‚Äù agents do the planning and design, then the ‚ÄúScrum Master/developer‚Äù agents write the actual code. The upside is a thorough workflow that stays orderly‚Äîideal for large, complex projects that demand clear documentation and division of labor. The downside is that it is cumbersome to use, has a steep learning curve, and expects the underlying model to truly understand the documentation you write.

Spec-Kit ‚Äì an open-source utility on GitHub that layers a bit of ‚Äúprocess‚Äù on top of your existing AI coding assistant. Developers use the command line to nudge AI through a ‚ÄúSpecification ‚Üí Plan ‚Üí Tasks ‚Üí Implementation‚Äù four-step. In short, Spec-Kit asks you to nail the requirements first, then guides AI to break work down and produce code. It turns your specification markdown into an ‚Äúexecutable document‚Äù using commands like /specify, /plan, and /tasks. It is lightweight and flexible, does not force you to revamp your workflow, and is model-agnostic. Great for solo builders or small teams that want to add structure and improve AI-generated code quality.

OpenSpec ‚Äì a minimalist newcomer that believes ‚Äúsimple is better.‚Äù You write a slim Markdown spec and pair it with a handful of commands to finish the job. Its flow has only three steps: submit a change proposal, let AI produce the task list, then let AI apply the spec to modify the code. The highlight is efficiency: the specs stay lean, token usage stays low, and there is barely any metadata. It works well for individuals or small teams chasing extreme speed‚Äîminor tweaks get done in minutes. The trade-off is that model support is still limited, but it is so easy to learn that there is almost no overhead.

Spot the pattern? These tools share the same philosophy: document first, then drive the AI. The goal is to reduce the uncertainty of vibe coding by giving AI a clear rulebook so code quality becomes controllable. Ideal in theory‚Äîbut reality bites. If you are not careful, the documentation you create can morph into another giant spaghetti pile. Why does that happen? Read on.

Four Reasons Documentation Turns into a Spaghetti Mountain Even Faster

Section titled ‚ÄúFour Reasons Documentation Turns into a Spaghetti Mountain Even Faster‚Äù

1. Lack of Structure

Section titled ‚Äú1. Lack of Structure‚Äù

Code is constrained by syntax‚Äîone misplaced comma and it will not even run. Documentation is much freer, and AI is not human. When a model stares at free-form, meandering text, its comprehension goes sideways. Code is deterministic; specifications are often vague and open to interpretation. If your documentation is loosely structured, the AI sees the world through fogged glass, and it is no surprise when the code it generates veers off in the wrong direction.

2. Inconsistent AI Understanding

Section titled ‚Äú2. Inconsistent AI Understanding‚Äù

Even if you write a decent document, there is no guarantee the AI will interpret it the same way every time. Seasoned developers know the saying ‚Äúa thousand readers, a thousand Hamlets‚Äù‚Äîand AI thinks even more differently from humans. ChatGPT might implement the feature correctly today, but a different model tomorrow could distort your intent. Documentation lacks the compiler‚Äôs safety net, so misunderstandings can hide in plain sight and quietly plant landmines.

3. AI Hallucinations Amplify Errors

Section titled ‚Äú3. AI Hallucinations Amplify Errors‚Äù

We all know large language models hallucinate‚Äîconfidently fabricating details. When AI uses incomplete or ambiguous documentation to write code, the stakes rise. Miss a detail in your spec and the AI might ‚Äúfill in the gaps‚Äù with something that looks plausible but is wrong. Worse still, if that flawed AI-generated documentation or code gets reused later, another AI might treat it as gospel truth. Errors balloon like rumors: once they make it into formal docs, people and models alike will keep getting misled.

4. New Risks Introduced by the Tools Themselves

Section titled ‚Äú4. New Risks Introduced by the Tools Themselves‚Äù

Finally, consider the complexity of the tools. Adopting Spec-Kit or BMAD might require extra software and brand-new rituals. You can end up wrestling with tooling, pouring hours into crafting specs and calibrating workflows, while actual coding time shrinks. If you do not internalize the framework, you may copy templates mechanically, letting documentation drift away from the code. Like wielding a scalpel without training‚Äîthe damage can be greater than doing nothing.

How to Avoid the Pile-Up: A Tiered Playbook for Documentation Tools

Section titled ‚ÄúHow to Avoid the Pile-Up: A Tiered Playbook for Documentation Tools‚Äù

The pitfalls sound daunting, but do not lose heart. With a tiered usage strategy, documentation-driven programming can still pave a smoother road:

Use direct prompts for tiny tweaks

Section titled ‚ÄúUse direct prompts for tiny tweaks‚Äù

When you are only adjusting a small logic branch or styling tweak, there is no need to assemble a grand spec. In these cases, asking Claude Code, Codex, Gemini, GitHub Copilot, or Cursor directly is fastest. Explain the request in a sentence or two and let the AI offer a diff or snippet. You save time and stay focused. As veterans like to say: small asks do not need the full ceremony; if a quick chat solves it, skip the paperwork.

Reach for Spec-Kit or OpenSpec on medium-sized changes

Section titled ‚ÄúReach for Spec-Kit or OpenSpec on medium-sized changes‚Äù

If you are adding a mid-sized feature‚Äîmultiple steps, not massive‚Äîconsider a lightweight tool such as Spec-Kit or OpenSpec. Spend ten minutes drafting an MVP-level spec that captures key requirements and edge cases, then hand it to the AI to refine the plan and tasks. Spec-Kit decomposes work item by item; OpenSpec minimizes context switching and handles the change in a few commands. The key is to keep the spec concise, covering only what is necessary. Data shows that compact specs are easier for AI to execute faithfully and more efficient overall. Once the feature ships, remember to update canonical docs or clean up temporary specs to prevent outdated information from piling up.

Deploy BMAD for major overhauls

Section titled ‚ÄúDeploy BMAD for major overhauls‚Äù

For large-scale refactors or brand-new complex subsystems‚Äîthe real ‚Äúsurgery‚Äù‚Äîyou need a rigorous approach. This is where a multi-agent framework like BMAD earns its keep: it orchestrates end-to-end planning, architecture, and task allocation. Think of it as hiring a virtual AI team to keep big projects on the rails. Of course, humans must stay in the loop‚Äînever blindly accept each AI output; review and adjust. Before spinning up BMAD, weigh the costs: it takes time and demands strong model comprehension. That investment can pay off for long-lived initiatives, but the documentation it produces‚Äîspecs, user stories, and more‚Äîshould evolve with the code. Do not toss it aside after one run; maintain it alongside the project or you will be rebuilding from scratch next time.

No matter the scale, remember the ‚Äúdocumentation MVP‚Äù principle: the doc should cover only what is necessary and true right now. Do not chase completeness for its own sake. Many veterans delete temporary specs once a feature is done because the code itself is already clear. Instead of hoarding outdated notes that mislead people, keep a lean, accurate reference and update it as the product evolves. Documentation earns its value by reflecting reality; once it drifts, it is just dead weight.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Documentation-driven programming is a double-edged sword in the AI era. Used well, it makes development more efficient and orderly; misused, it spawns fresh spaghetti mountains. Ambitious young engineers should absolutely explore new tools, but not worship them blindly. Whether we are talking code or docs, the heart of the matter is understanding the requirement and keeping information current. Whenever you decide to write a spec or pick a tool, ask yourself: ‚ÄúIs this making the problem clearer‚Äîor just adding complexity?‚Äù

Here‚Äôs to every developer mastering these AI tools, producing docs that stay crisp and useful, and turning documentation into an asset‚Äînot a burden. We all want higher productivity, not a literal spaghetti mountain blocking the office! üí©

item.content:encoded:
Use a real-world case to expose the pain points of iOS BLE and the divergent reasoning paths of Codex and Claude Code as AI assistants.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Takeaways Cheat Sheet (with Authoritative References)‚Äù
  • CoreBluetooth discovery and callbacks are asynchronous. Operate only after the corresponding callbacks (such as discoverServices or discoverCharacteristics:forService:) complete; precise UUID searches are more efficient.
  • ‚ÄúDiscover first, then act‚Äù is the conventional order for iOS BLE. Tutorials and field guides emphasize callback-driven, asynchronous thinking to avoid writing before discovery finishes.
